chapter.htmlHeader: When should I arrange a breast milk culture?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Breast milk culture is not routinely required in primary care for women with mastitis.
    • However, in women with lactational mastitis, send a sample of breast milk for microscopy, culture, and antibiotic sensitivity, if:
      • Mastitis is severe or recurrent, or presentation is unusual.
      • Hospital-acquired infection is likely.
      • There is severe deep 'burning' breast pain (indicative of ductal infection).
    • Advise the women on how to collect a sample of breast milk. She should:
      • Clean the nipple of the affected breast.
      • Express a small amount of milk by hand and discard it (to avoid skin contamination).
      • Express milk into a sterile container, avoiding touching the inside of the container with the nipple or hands.
  • All women with a breast abscess should be urgently referred to secondary care for confirmation of the diagnosis and management — see Scenario: Management - breast abscess for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on investigations for mastitis are largely based on expert opinion in the World Health Organization (WHO) guideline Mastitis. Causes and management [WHO, 2000], the Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine (ABM) guideline ABM Clinical protocol number 4: mastitis [Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine, 2014], the Health Service Executive Ireland Mastitis: Fact sheet for Health Care Professionals [Health Service Executive Ireland, 2017], and the BMJ Best Practice guideline Mastitis and breast abscess [BMJ Best Practice, 2020].

Breast milk culture 

  • Breast milk culture is not routinely recommended in primary care for women with mastitis because [WHO, 2000; Betzold, 2007; BMJ Best Practice, 2020]:
    • The presence of bacteria in the milk does not necessarily indicate infection.
    • Many women with mastitis may not have pathogenic organisms in their milk.
    • Bacterial counts are not always reliable, for example because breast milk from non-infected areas of the breast may dilute or flush out the pathogen, or the flow of milk from the infected area may be obstructed.
  • The recommendations on when breast milk culture should be performed are based on expert opinion in the WHO guideline Mastitis [WHO, 2000], the ABM guideline ABM Clinical protocol number 4: mastitis [Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine, 2014], the Health Service Executive Ireland Mastitis: Fact sheet for Health Care Professionals [Health Service Executive Ireland, 2017], the BMJ Best Practice guideline Mastitis and breast abscess, and a review article on the management of lactational breast inflammation [Betzold, 2007].
  • The information on how a sample of breast milk should be collected derives from expert opinion in the ABM guideline ABM Clinical protocol number 4: mastitis [Academy of Breastfeeding Medicine, 2014], the Health Service Executive Ireland Mastitis: Fact sheet for Health Care Professionals [Health Service Executive Ireland, 2017], and a review article on the management of lactational mastitis [Spencer, 2008].

Urgent secondary care referral for all women with a breast abscess

  • The recommendation to arrange urgent secondary care referral for all women with a breast abscess is based on expert opinion in the WHO guideline Mastitis [WHO, 2000] and in review articles on the management of breast inflammation and infection [Mass, 2004; Betzold, 2007; Spencer, 2008; Dixon, 2011].
    • Ultrasound examination is required to accurately diagnose a breast abscess [BMJ Best Practice, 2020].
    • Antibiotic treatment alone without removal of pus is unlikely to be curative. However, ultrasonography-guided aspiration may be curative [WHO, 2000].
    • Even when clinical examination shows signs of an abscess, an ultrasound is useful because it may identify more than one collection of pus that may otherwise be missed [Dixon, 2011].
